Award.AwardTitle: Precision Experiments with Cold and Ultracold Neutrons
Award.AbstractNarration:
Research in Fundamental Nuclear and Particle Physics is being categorized in three areas: At the "Energy Frontier", physicists hope to discover new physics, e.g. new symmetries or particles, by colliding particles with increasingly high energy. At the "Cosmic Frontier", physicists use the cosmos as a laboratory that contains detectable information about new physics. And finally, at the "Precision Frontier", physicists attempt to measure quantities that are believed to be known very precisely, and to interpret deviations from the known physics predictions as a signal for new physics. This award supports a measurement of the third type, a precision measurement of several observables in free neutron beta decay which serve to better understand the fundamental interactions between elementary particles. The process of beta decay has been incorporated into the standard model of elementary particle physics, which gives us a successful description of elementary particle processes. A discovery of new physics would have a critical impact on Nuclear and High Energy Physics, and on Cosmology. Being on the forefront of scientific research and on the edge of what is technologically feasible, the project will serve as a training ground for future generations of scientists. Most of the research will be done by students at the undergraduate and graduate level.

This grant supports the effort to design, construct, commission, and operate the Nab spectrometer. The spectrometer will use the state of the art neutron beamline (FNPB) at the new Spallation Neutron Source (SNS) in Oak Ridge, TN to determine the two-dimensional energy distribution of decay electron and protons in neutron beta decay. The redundancy inherent in the standard model description of the neutron beta decay process allows uniquely sensitive checks of the model's validity and limits, with strong implications in astrophysics. One of the expected observables, the determination of the neutrino-electron-correlation coefficient with a relative uncertainty of 0.1%, will allow an extraction of Vud, the upper left element of the Cabbibo-Kobayashi-Maskawa (CKM) matrix, in order to test its unitarity. The current NSAC long range plan finds that "The only realistic way to improve Vud is via neutron decay." New results from high energy physics cast a shadow on the unitarity of the CKM matrix, and re-open the possibility of finding hints for new exchange bosons, or a fourth quark generation. The other observable, the determination of the Fierz term, which parametrizes a deviation from the known shape of the spectrum of the decay electrons, to about 0.001, allows finding new particles that mediate scalar or tensor interactions at low energy, in a complementary way and with sensitivity competitive to what is expected from LHC.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant supported the effort to design, construct, commission, and operate the Nab spectrometer. The spectrometer uses the state of the art neutron beamline (FNPB) at the new Spallation Neutron Source (SNS) in Oak Ridge/TN to determine the two-dimensional energy distribution of decay electron and protons in neutron beta decay. The Principal Investigator (PI) is the project manager. A description of the theory of operation of the spectrometer and its expected performance has been published as part of a larger review in J. Phys. G. in 2014, with the PI being the lead author.

An experimental highlight of the work of the PI?s group was the fabrication, delivery, and testing of the Nab spectrometer magnet. The magnet met all acceptance criteria. In particular, the magnetic field matches the design specifications, and the residual gas pressure in its bore tube has been shown to be an order of magnitude better than expected. The PI is also responsible for the main electrode system. The critical specification is that the electrostatic potential in the electrode system?s interior varies by less than 10 mV, so as not to falsify the proton energy determination through proton time-of-flight. The PI?s group identified a new type of electrode surface coating that achieves a sufficiently uniform work function. The electrode system has been assembled and coated in September 2018. Another highlight is the development of an ultra-stable low-energy proton source that will be needed for the calibration of the Nab detector; the stability achieved is <300 ppm/hour. The Nab experiment has started installation at the Fundamental Physics Beamline of the Spallation Neutron Source at Oak Ridge National Lab, and the collaboration is looking forward to the start commissioning and taking physics data maybe in a few months.

It is worth mentioning that the preceding grant included support for data taking and analysis of the npdgamma experiment, which measured the gamma asymmetry in the (n,p) reaction with respect to the neutron spin. The final result is a small, but non-zero value for the gamma asymmetry, which shows that the long-range (one-pion exchange) component of the weak interaction between nucleons is unexpectedly small. The outcomes of the research from this grant have been published in various publications that are listed in the project final report. For npdgamma, the main publication has just been accepted in Phys. Rev. Lett., and has been selected as an Editor?s pick. We have no citation information yet.

The NSF grant made a major impact in the education of students: Huangxing Li, graduate student, has been working on the design, construction, and characterization of the Nab electrode system, and has performed studies of the systematic uncertainties expected with the Nab spectrometer. His results are the basis for his Ph.D. thesis, with a defense planned for 2019. The proton source was first conceived as an undergraduate research project, and fifteen undergraduate students worked on the project. Americo Salas Bacci, research scientist, has taken over the project lead; he deserves most of the credit for the proton source optimization, and he gained valuable mentorship experience with many of the students, which has been supporting his applications for permanent scientist positions. Furthermore, two undergraduate students have worked on the design, construction, and commissioning of a Stern-Gerlach filter for the GRANIT experiment (the study of gravitationally bound neutrons in quantum states), and one of them (a female) has received the annual Undergraduate Research Prize of the Physics Department for the best undergraduate research of the graduating class of 2016.
